Award.AwardTitle: Multi-scale climate information for agricultural planning in southeastern South America for coming decades
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigators (PIs) will investigate the development of decadal-scale climate information and its use in agricultural sector applications for southeastern South America, where almost half of the world's soybeans are grown. This region exhibits notable interannual variability, decadal variability and long-term trends. It thus constitutes a suitable setting to understand past climate changes that enabled agricultural expansion and apply this new knowledge to decision systems that inform further development and reduce vulnerability. The project will incorporate a range of model simulations and predictions together with historical climate observations. The PIs will analyze the past using statistical and dynamical techniques that target the characteristics of future weather and climate varying on decadal timescales. The agricultural context will dictate the spatial and temporal scale of climate information required for use in soil and crop models, as well as the sensitivity of agricultural decision systems to uncertainty in the climate at different timescales.

The broader impacts of this project are high: it is anticipated that the methodological framework will be transferable to other regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The climate varies on all timescales. Those who manage or plan resources or systems impacted by climate should factor in climate variability and change, and often on more than a single timescale. For example, a region may be projected to get wetter under climate change, and may have even experienced a long-term trend towards wetter conditions, but may still experience devastating drought periods. An example of this is the Southern Eastern South America (SESA), where the agricultural frontier has expanded drastically since 1990 due in part to increased annual precipitation over regions traditionally considered semiarid. Soybean-sown area in this region has increased by more than 160% between 1990 and 2007, and production has tripled; the region now produces 44% of the world’s soybeans. Agricultural decision makers in this region desire reliable decadal-scale outlooks for planning and management, but none exist currently.  The objective of this project was to understand, design, and apply information on climate variability and change to inform agricultural planning and risk management on the 10-20 year time-horizon. The sectoral and regional context serves as a test bed for the development of decadal climate information.

The SESA region has experienced one of the largest wetting trends on Earth; the trend accounts for approximately 30% of the precipitation variance over the 20th Century. Our research demonstrated that this trend was due not just to increasing greenhouse gasses (GHGs) but also to ozone depletion over the South Pole. Both factors contributed to the increased rainfall in the region, but it is still difficult to say which driver dominated the process. Currently, the ozone hole is recovering, but GHGs keep accumulating in the atmosphere. This takes a problem of man-made climate change, often assumed to constitute just a long-term trend, and transforms it back to a decadal-scale problem. We can account for that range of possibilities though, as we design future scenarios of climate change, in a way that the global climate models do not capture.

Natural climate variability on interannual-to-decadal scales, and even the changing risk of extreme weather, must also be accounted for. The skill of experimental decadal climate predictions are not yet ready for direct use in forecast outlooks, so a method of stochastic simulations of past climate was developed to probabilistically account for the likely magnitude and persistence of wet and dry periods. This methodology maintained spatial coherence and co-variability in temperature and precipitation, which is important to the ecological thresholds of crops and also the yield outlooks for the region. These stochastic simulations add back in the assumed trends and thus can compare the multi-decadal scenarios in which the ozone hole recovery returns regional rainfall to historical patterns against those where GHGs keep regional rainfall high. The simulated crop yields for the region under the different long-term trend scenarios, respond as expected in that an ongoing wet (GHG dominated) trend will lead to increases, and a return to previous values (ozone dominated) will lead to decreases relative to present. Furthermore, relatively wet or dry decadal periods superimposed on the trends will yield a similar expected response.

Even with large trends, year-to-year variability of rainfall dominates, and is where most of the economic and social shocks are experienced.
